Figure 1.2.1A: Cross-section from A to B through a mature mid-latitude cyclone 
(from synoptic view in Figure 1.2.3A)
As a mid-latitude cyclone moves towards South Africa, it is the cold front 
that mostly affects our weather (see Figure 1.2.1C on page 8).
Weather in front of the cold front (see point 1 in Figure 1.2.1A above):
â¢ 
Cool temperatures
â¢ 
Very low pressure
â¢ 
Overcast conditions, cumulonimbus clouds
â¢ 
Thunderstorms
Weather behind the cold front (see point 2 in Figure 1.2.1A above):
â¢ 
Cold temperatures
â¢ 
High pressure
â¢ 
Partly cloudy conditions, cumulus clouds
â¢ 
Light rain
Note that as a mid-latitude cyclone moves from west to east, we experience 
the warm air mass in front of the cold front first, then the air behind the 
cold front. This can be seen in Figure 1.2.1A (above) as you move over from 
point 1 to 2.
Figure 1.2.1B (below) shows the weather conditions before and after the 
cold front.
In front of the cold front
The cold front
Behind the cold front
Cumulus
Overcast
Cumulonimbus
Partly 
cloudy
High pressure
Cold
Light rain
Figure 1.2.1B: Weather conditions before and after the cold front
Very low pressure
To prepare  
better for the exam  
and understand  this topic 
better, read  up on the 
weather associated with the  
warm front and  
warm sector.
Learn to  
redraw Figure 1.2.1A 
and label it. You must be 
able to describe the weather 
that occurs with a 
mid-latitude  
cyclone.
